questions.question_text: What are characteristics of Amazon S3? (Choose two.)
questions.answer_description:
The total volume of data and number of objects you can store are unlimited. Individual Amazon S3 objects can range in size from a minimum of 0 bytes to a maximum of 5 terabytes. The largest object that can be uploaded in a single PUT is 5 gigabytes. For objects larger than 100 megabytes, customers should consider using the Multipart Upload capability.
Reference:
https://aws.amazon.com/s3/faqs/

choices.D: S3 allows you to store virtually unlimited amounts of data
choices.C: S3 allows you to store objects or virtually unlimited size
choices.B: S3 should be used to host a relational database
choices.A: Objects are directly accessible via a URL

discussion.content:
A | D are the answers

You can access any file within any bucket by using its URL (A) and you have unlimited space to store your files (D)

comments.content:
"The total volume of data and number of objects you can store are unlimited." 
So yes: A & D

discussion.content:
A. Objects are directly accessible via a URL
D. S3 allows you to store virtually unlimited amounts of data

questions.answer_description:
A dimension is a key-value pair used to uniquely identify a metric. CloudWatch treats each unique combination of dimensions as a separate metric. Thus, if the user is making 4 calls with the same metric name but a separate dimension, it will create 4 separate metrics.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/DeveloperGuide/cloudwatch_concepts.html
questions.question_text: A user is sending a custom metric to CloudWatch. If the call to the CloudWatch APIs has different dimensions, but the same metric name, how will CloudWatch treat all the requests?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When sending a custom metric to CloudWatch, if the calls to the CloudWatch APIs have different dimensions but the same metric name, CloudWatch treats each unique combination of dimensions as a separate metric. This means that even if the metric name is the same, the different dimensions provided will create distinct metrics within CloudWatch.

Dimensions are used to further categorize and filter metrics in CloudWatch. By including different dimensions, you can create multiple instances of the same metric with varying characteristics or attributes.

CloudWatch considers the combination of the metric name and dimensions to uniquely identify a metric. Therefore, if you send multiple requests with the same metric name but different dimensions, CloudWatch will treat them as separate metrics.
A. It will treat each unique combination of dimensions as a separate metric.

choices.C: It will overwrite the previous dimension data with the new dimension data.
choices.D: It will reject the request as there cannot be a separate dimension for a single metric.
choices.A: It will treat each unique combination of dimensions as a separate metric.
choices.B: It will group all the calls into a single call.

choices.C: It is not possible to disable monitoring of the estimated charges.
choices.D: AWS will stop sending the billing alerts to the user.
choices.B: The data collection on estimated charges is stopped.
choices.A: The user cannot edit the existing billing alarm.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If a user wants to stop monitoring the estimated charges and disable the associated billing alarm, they would need to delete or deactivate the billing alarm in the AWS account. Disabling monitoring or stopping data collection for estimated charges alone is not a separate option.

Selected Answer: C
You can't disable data collection one billing alert is enabled (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/monitoring/monitor_estimated_charges_with_cloudwatch.html)

"moni-toring"?
lol, but yeah I agree with C.

questions.question_text: A user has enabled the CloudWatch alarm to estimate the usage charges. If the user disables moni-toring of the estimated charges but does not delete the billing alert from the AWS account, what will happen?

questions.answer_description:
By default, a load balancer routes each request independently to the registered instance with the smallest load. However, you can use the sticky session feature
(also known as session affinity), which enables the load balancer to bind a user's session to a specific instance. This ensures that all requests from the user during the session are sent to the same instance.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/elb-sticky-sessions.html
questions.question_text: What does enabling a sticky session with ELB do?

choices.B: Ensures that all requests from the user's session are sent to multiple instances
choices.D: Provides a single ELB DNS for each IP address
choices.C: Binds the user session with a specific instance
choices.A: Routes all the requests to a single DNS

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
When sticky sessions are enabled, the load balancer associates the user's session with a specific backend instance. This ensures that all requests from that user's session are consistently routed to the same instance.

questions.answer_description:
An Auto Scaling group can contain EC2 instances that come from one or more Availability Zones within the same region. However, an Auto Scaling group cannot span multiple regions.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/US_AddAvailabilityZone.html

choices.C: Auto Scaling publishes new log files about every 15 minutes.
choices.D: An Auto Scaling group cannot be configured to scale automatically.
choices.A: An Auto Scaling group cannot span multiple regions.
choices.B: An Auto Scaling group delivers log files within 30 minutes of an API call.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true of an Auto Scaling group?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
While you can create Auto Scaling groups in different regions, each Auto Scaling group is specific to its respective region and cannot span across multiple regions. The scaling policies and instances within an Auto Scaling group are limited to the resources available within a single region.

A
An Auto Scaling group can contain EC2 instances in one or more Availability Zones within the same Region. However, Auto Scaling groups cannot span multiple Regions.
